_exec_summary.SummaryText:
EXECUTIVE SUMMARY (40 CFR 68.155)



INTRODUCTION



At the KRATON Polymers Belpre Plant, we are committed to operating and maintaining all of our processes in a safe and responsible manner.  We use a combination of accidental release prevention programs and emergency response planning programs to help ensure the safety of our employees and the public as well as protection of the environment.  This document provides a brief overview of the comprehensive risk management activities that we have designed and implemented, including:



    The accidental release prevention and emergency response policies

    A description of our facility and use of substances regulated by EPA's RMP  

         regulation

    A summary of results from our assessment of the potential offsite consequences 

         from accidental chemical releases

    An overview of our general accidental release prevention programs and chemical 

         specific prevention steps

    A five-year accident history for accidental releases of chemicals regulated by

         EPA's RMP rule

    An overview of our emergency response program

    Planned changes to improve safety



ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE POLICIES



Kraton complies with NFPA requirements as well as other chemical industry standards.  It is our policy to adhere to all applicable federal, state, and local laws.  If an emergency were to occur, we would implement our Emergency Response Plan based on the level of the emergency.  The site maintains an emergency brigade capable of handling the majority of emergencies the site may experience.  Outside aide is also available from the Little Hocking Fire Department and the Belpre Fire Department.  Traffic control, when necessary, is provided by the Washington County Sheriff's Department.  In addition, Kraton has joined with other companies in an organization known as COVIEO, whose purpose is to furnish fire fighting equipment and first aid material to a distressed member company.



STAT

IONARY SOURCE AND REGULATED SUBSTANCES



The KRATON Belpre Plant produces KRATON; and SHELLVIS; thermoplastic elastomers using a variety of chemicals and processing operations.  Our facility includes four polymer production units, a compounding unit, steam generation, wastewater treatment, and other support services.  We store the following RMP regulated substances (chemicals that EPA has identified as having the potential to cause significant offsite consequences in the event of a substantial accidental release) in our processes in quantities greater than the thresholds listed in 40 CFR 68.



Chemical                           Use                         Hazard

1,3-Butadiene                           Raw Material                 Flammable

Ethyl Ether [Ethane,1,1 oxybis-]       Processing Aid                 Flammable

Hydrogen                           Raw Material                 Flammable

Isoprene [1,3-butadiene,2-methyl-]     Raw material                 Flammable



The accidental release prevention programs and our contingency planning efforts help effectively manage the hazards that may be posed to our employees, the public, and the environment by the use of these chemicals on this site.



WORST CASE AND ALTERNATIVE CASE SCENARIOS



The worst-case scenario for the RMP involves the complete loss of the contents of the 1,3-Butadiene storage tank. In this scenario, a catastrophic failure of the vessel occurs, and its entire contents are released nearly immediately (in under 1 minute). This failure and release results in a vapor cloud explosion in which the entire mass of 1,3-butadiene is consumed. The estimated distance to the 1 psi overpressure endpoint of 1 psi (as calculated by USEPA's RMP*Comp) is 1.4 miles. This distance to the endpoint extends offsite and includes public receptors within its range. 



Our alternate case flammable scenario is a pressure relief valve lifting on a vaporizer vessel at the 1,3-Butadiene barge unloading facility occurring for 1 minute.  The dis

tance to the endpoint extends offsite to a wetland and to the Ohio River, a recreational area.  No residences or other public receptors are located within that distance.  No other reasonable flammable scenario extends farther or impacts different populations.



Kraton no longer stores ammonia or chlorine on site.



GENERAL ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM AND CHEMICAL-SPECIFIC PREVENTION STEPS



We take a systematic, proactive approach to preventing accidental releases of hazardous chemicals. Facility operations and activities are regulated by rules from a number of Agencies, including US EPA, Ohio EPA, and OSHA.  Our management systems address each of the key features of successful prevention programs as noted in the OSHA Process Safety Management System including:



    Process safety information

    Process hazard analysis

    Operating procedures

    Training

    Mechanical integrity

    Management of change

    Pre-startup safety reviews

    Compliance audits

    Incident investigation

    Employee participation

    Hot work permit

    Contractors

    Emergency Response Program



As part of our prevention efforts, we have implemented the following chemical-specific prevention steps: 



1.    A prevention effort specific to this facility is a triple redundancy polymerization safety system ("Poly Safety System").  The Poly Safety System is designed to prevent runaway polymerization reactions by ensuring more energy is never placed into a reactor than can be safely contained.  



2.    The employees of the KRATON Plant are dedicated to continuous safety improvement. All chemicals are treated with equal respect when it comes to release prevention.  Ongoing training, procedure review, auditing, and process improvements support progress toward our goal of an accident and injury-free workplace.



3.    The individual elements of our prevention program work together to prevent accidental chemical releases.  Our company and our employees are committed to the standard that these management sys

tems have established for the way we do business. We have specific accountabilities and controls to ensure that we are meeting our own high standards for accident prevention.  



FIVE-YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY



We keep records for all accidental chemical releases that occur at the facility.  Kraton has had two events occur in the past 5 years with respect to the listed chemicals.  On January 9, 2014, a release of 4,379 pounds of dietyl ether occurred from a failed heat exchanger due to freezing conditions.   The release affected the water and ambient air over the Ohio River which resulted in 550 fish fatalities.  There was no impact to the surrounding community or public water systems. On August 13, 2018, a release of 1645 pounds of Isoprene occurred due to a fire in the Tank Farm when a pump ignited into flames. The release affected the ambient air over the Ohio River, however, no injuries resulted from the incident. There was no impact to the surrounding community or the waterways.  



All significant accidental releases of chemicals are formally investigated to identify and correct the root cause of the events.  Less significant events are also investigated so that we can learn from them and prevent future incidents.



EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM



We maintain an Emergency Response Plan, a Spill Prevention Control and Countermeasures Plan, a Stormwater Pollution Prevention Plan, a Hazardous Waste Contingency Plan, and a Facility Response Plan to assure appropriate emergency response.  Our programs provide the facilities, planning, and training and have been developed to assure protection of workers, the public, and the environment during emergency situations.  We conduct periodic drills and critiques of events in order to continuously improve our response capability.   Furthermore, we coordinate our plan with the community emergency response plan and are represented on the Washington County Local Emergency Planning Committee.  



PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFE

TY



This facility is dedicated to continuous safety improvement.  Changes to improve safety and environmental performance occur regularly. The following is a partial listing of some of the activities the facility uses to identify opportunities for improvement in order to continuously improve process safety and prevent and/or better respond to accidental chemical releases:



    Process Hazards Analyses and follow up on recommendations and issues

    Periodic audits conducted by both site employees as well as third party auditors

    Systematic review of safety, environmental, and emergency response procedures

    Inspections and audits of procedures and field practices

    Safety committees and periodic safety meetings to discuss requirements and issues

    Incident and near-miss investigations using systematic root cause analysis 

         techniques

    Operating procedures, safety procedures, and various process safety information 

         are available on-line to ensure easy access and current information

    A contractor safety council meets routinely to share information and discuss 

         issues for resolution

    Ongoing training of emergency response personnel
